title: Survivorship Bias
story: During WWII, analysts studied returning bombers to decide where to add armor. Abraham Wald pointed out the fatal flaw: they were only seeing the planes that survived.
what_is_missing: Damage on planes that never came back.
moral: Visible evidence is biased toward success.
enterprise_ux_translation: Your happy-path demo is the plane that returned. The real UX problems are in failed setups, abandoned workflows, and midnight outages.
citations: Wald, A. (1943). Statistical Research Group, Columbia University.

title: Streetlight Effect
story: A drunk searches for lost keys under a streetlight—not because that’s where he dropped them, but because that’s where the light is.
what_people_see: Data that is easy to collect.
what_is_missing: Data that is hard, expensive, or uncomfortable to obtain.
enterprise_ux_translation: Analytics show clicks and flows, but not confusion, workarounds, or shadow IT usage.
citations: Kaplan, A. (1964). The Conduct of Inquiry.

title: Conway’s Law
story: Systems mirror the communication structures of the organizations that build them.
what_is_missing: Org charts, incentives, and power structures.
enterprise_ux_translation: Inconsistent UX often reflects team boundaries, not user intent.
citations: Conway, M. (1968). How Do Committees Invent?

title: Goodhart’s Law
story: When a measure becomes a target, it stops being a good measure.
enterprise_ux_translation: Designing for adoption metrics can produce shallow usage instead of real value.
citations: Goodhart, C. (1975). Problems of Monetary Management.

title: The Cobra Effect
story: A bounty on cobras led people to breed cobras—making the problem worse.
moral: Incentives change systems, not just behavior.
enterprise_ux_translation: Forcing usage through mandates creates checkbox behavior, not engagement.
citations: Siebert, H. (2001). The Economic Consequences of Globalization.

title: Local vs Global Optimization
story: Each team optimizes its part, but the system gets worse overall.
moral: Optimizing parts can harm the whole.
enterprise_ux_translation: Great individual screens don’t guarantee a usable workflow.

title: Availability Heuristic
story: People judge likelihood based on how easily examples come to mind.
moral: Memorable problems crowd out important ones.
enterprise_ux_translation: Support tickets skew roadmap decisions toward loud customers.

title: Normalization of Deviance
story: Small failures become acceptable until catastrophe occurs.
moral: Absence of failure is not proof of safety.
enterprise_ux_translation: Fragile workflows become institutional knowledge instead of design fixes.
citations: Vaughan, D. (1996). The Challenger Launch Decision.

title: The Map Is Not the Territory
story: Models simplify reality—but are often mistaken for reality itself.
enterprise_ux_translation: User journeys hide exception paths that dominate real usage.

title: Power Law of Effort
story: Most users only use the simplest part of any system.
enterprise_ux_translation: Admin-heavy tools fail when basic tasks aren’t effortless.

title: Hick’s Law
story: More choices increase decision time and error.
enterprise_ux_translation: Over-configurable products slow down operators under pressure.
citations: Hick, W. (1952). On the Rate of Gain of Information.

title: The Curse of Knowledge
story: Once you know something, it’s hard to imagine not knowing it.
enterprise_ux_translation: Tools designed by experts punish new users.
citations: Camerer et al. (1989). The Curse of Knowledge.

title: Second-Order Effects
story: The real impact shows up later, elsewhere.
enterprise_ux_translation: Quick UX patches increase long-term operational cost.

title: Bus Factor
story: How many people can disappear before the system collapses?
moral: Single points of failure are invisible until too late.

title: False Consensus Effect
story: We assume others think like us.
enterprise_ux_translation: Internal dogfooding hides real usability gaps.
citations: Ross et al. (1977). False Consensus Effect.

title: Invisible Work
story: Most effort goes into preventing failure, not producing output.
enterprise_ux_translation: Admin UX matters more than end-user polish.

title: Regression to the Mean
story: Extreme outcomes tend to normalize naturally.
enterprise_ux_translation: Not every improvement is caused by the redesign.

title: The Silent Majority
enterprise_ux_translation: Lack of complaints often means abandonment, not satisfaction.
citations: Nielsen Norman Group. User Feedback Myths.
